etymologies: late Middle English (also denoting the function or office of a deputy, especially a papal legate): from Old French legacie, from medieval Latin legatia ‘legateship’, from legatus ‘person delegated’ (see legate)

definitions: an amount of money or property left to someone in a will

examples.text: my grandmother died and unexpectedly left me a small legacy

shortDefinitions: amount of money or property left to someone in will

definitions: something left or handed down by a predecessor

examples.text: the legacy of centuries of neglect

shortDefinitions: something left or handed down by predecessor

definitions: an applicant to a particular college or university who is regarded preferentially because a parent or other relative attended the same institution

examples.text: being a legacy increased a student's chance of being accepted to a highly selective college by up to 45 per cent

shortDefinitions: university applicant regarded preferentially because relative attended

definitions: denoting or relating to software or hardware that has been superseded but is difficult to replace because of its wide use.
shortDefinitions: denoting or relating to software or hardware that has been superseded but is difficult to replace because of its wide use
